classes.name: Ink_1
classes.text:
Ink Core.
This module provides the necessary methods to create and load the modules using Ink.

functions.name: getPath
functions.text:
Get the full path of a module.
This method looks up the paths given in setPath (and ultimately the default Ink's path).

params.name: key
params.description: Name of the module you want to get the path

params.name: noLib
params.description: Flag to skip appending 'lib.js' to the returned path.

functions.name: setPath
functions.text:
Sets the URL path for a namespace.
Use this to customize where requireModules and createModule will load dependencies from.
This can be useful to set your own CDN for dynamic module loading or simply to change your module folder structure

params.name: key
params.description: Module or namespace

params.name: rootURI
params.description: Base URL path and schema to be appended to the module or namespace

functions.name: loadScript
functions.text:
Loads a script URL.
This creates a `script` tag in the `head` of the document.
Reports errors by listening to 'error' and 'readystatechange' events.

params.name: uri
params.description: Can be an external URL or a module name

params.name: contentType
params.description: The `type` attribute of the new script tag.

functions.name: namespace
functions.text: Defines a module namespace.

params.name: ns
params.description: Namespace to define.

params.name: returnParentAndKey
params.description: Flag to change the return value to an array containing the namespace parent and the namespace key

return.description: Returns the created namespace object

functions.name: getModule
functions.text:
Loads a module.
A synchronous method to get the module from the registry. It assumes the module is defined and loaded already!

params.name: mod
params.description: Module name

params.name: version
params.description: Version number of the module

return.description: Module object or function, depending how the module is defined

functions.name: createModule
functions.text:
Creates a new module. 
Use this to wrap your code and benefit from the module loading used throughout the Ink library

params.name: mod
params.description: Module name, separated by dots. Like Ink.Dom.Selector, Ink.UI.Modal

params.name: version
params.description: Version number

params.name: deps
params.description: Array of module names which are dependencies of the module being created. The order in which they are passed here will define the order they will be passed to the callback function.

params.name: modFn
params.description: The callback function to be executed when all the dependencies are resolved. The dependencies are passed as arguments, in the same order they were declared. The function itself should return the module.

functions.name: requireModules
functions.text:
Requires modules asynchronously 
Use this to get modules, even if they're not loaded yet

params.name: deps
params.description: Array of module names. The order in which they are passed here will define the order they will be passed to the callback function.

params.name: cbFn
params.description: The callback function to be executed when all the dependencies are resolved. The dependencies are passed as arguments, in the same order they were declared.

functions.name: getModulesLoadOrder
functions.text:
Lists loaded module names.
The list is ordered by loaded time (oldest module comes first)

return.description: returns the order in which modules were resolved and correctly loaded

functions.name: getModuleScripts
functions.text:
Builds the markup needed to load the modules.
This method builds the script tags needed to load the currently used modules

return.description: The script markup

functions.name: createExt
functions.text:
Creates an Ink.Ext module

Does exactly the same as createModule but creates the module in the Ink.Ext namespace

params.name: moduleName
params.description: Extension name

params.name: version
params.description: Extension version

params.name: dependencies
params.description: Extension dependencies

params.name: modFn
params.description: Function returning the extension

functions.name: bind
functions.text:
Function.prototype.bind alternative.
Creates a new function that, when called, has its this keyword set to the provided value, with a given sequence of arguments preceding any provided when the new function is called.

params.name: fn
params.description: The function

params.name: context
params.description: The value to be passed as the this parameter to the target function when the bound function is called. If used as false, it preserves the original context and just binds the arguments.

params.name: args*
params.description: Additional arguments will be sent to the original function as prefix arguments.

functions.name: bindMethod
functions.text:
Function.prototype.bind alternative for class methods
Creates a new function that, when called, has this k

params.name: object
params.description: The object that contains the method to bind

params.name: methodName
params.description: The name of the method that will be bound

params.name: args*
params.description: Additional arguments will be sent to the new method as prefix arguments.

functions.name: bindEvent
functions.text:
Function.prototype.bind alternative for event handlers.
Same as bind but keeps first argument of the call the original event.
Set "context" to `false` to preserve the original context of the function and just bind the arguments.

params.name: fn
params.description: The function

params.name: context
params.description: The value to be passed as the this parameter to the target

params.name: args*
params.description: Additional arguments will be sent to the original function as prefix arguments

functions.name: i
functions.text: Alias to document.getElementById

params.name: id
params.description: Element ID

functions.name: ss
functions.text: Alias for Ink.Dom.Selector

return.description: array of DOMElements

functions.name: s
functions.text: Alias for Ink.Dom.Selector first result

params.name: rule
params.description: Selector string

params.name: from
params.description: Context element. If set to a DOM element, the rule will only look for descendants of this DOM Element.

functions.name: extendObj
functions.text:
Extends an object with another
Copy all of the properties in one or more source objects over to the destination object, and return the destination object. It's in-order, so the last source will override properties of the same name in previous arguments.

params.name: destination
params.description: The object that will receive the new/updated properties

params.name: source
params.description: The object whose properties will be copied over to the destination object

params.name: args*
params.description: Additional source objects. The last source will override properties of the same name in the previous defined sources

return.description: destination object, enriched with defaults from the sources

functions.name: log
functions.text: Calls native console.log if available.

params.name: args*
params.description: Arguments to be evaluated

functions.name: warn
functions.text: Calls native console.warn if available.

params.name: args*
params.description: Arguments to be evaluated

functions.name: error
functions.text: Calls native console.error if available.

params.name: args*
params.description: Arguments to be evaluated

modules.name: Ink.Dom.Browser_1

classes.name: Ink.Dom.Browser

functions.name: init
functions.text:
Initialization function for the Browser object.

Is called automatically when this module is loaded, and calls setDimensions, setBrowser and setReferrer.

functions.name: setDimensions
functions.text: Retrieves and stores window dimensions in this object. Called automatically when this module is loaded.

functions.name: setReferrer
functions.text: Stores the referrer. Called automatically when this module is loaded.

functions.name: detectBrowser
functions.text: Detects the browser and stores the found properties. Called automatically when this module is loaded.

functions.name: debug
functions.text: Debug function which displays browser (and Ink.Dom.Browser) information as an alert message.

attributes.name: IE
attributes.text: True if the browser is Internet Explorer

attributes.name: GECKO
attributes.text: True if the browser is Gecko based

attributes.name: OPERA
attributes.text: True if the browser is Opera

attributes.name: SAFARI
attributes.text: True if the browser is Safari

attributes.name: KONQUEROR
attributes.text: True if the browser is Konqueror

attributes.name: CHROME
attributes.text: True if browser is Chrome

attributes.name: model
attributes.text:
The specific browser model.
False if it is unavailable.

attributes.name: version
attributes.text:
The browser version.
False if it is unavailable.

attributes.name: userAgent
attributes.text:
The user agent string.
False if it is unavailable.

examples:
<script>
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.Dom.Browser_1'],function( InkBrowser ){
            if( InkBrowser.CHROME ){
                console.log( 'This is a CHROME browser.' );
            }
        });
    </script>

modules.version:
1
Browser Detection and User Agent sniffing

functions.name: addRemoveClassName
functions.text:
Adds of removes a class.
Depending on addRemState, this method either adds a class if it's true or removes if if false.

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: class name to add or remove.

params.name: addRemState
params.description: Whether to add or remove. `true` to add, `false` to remove.

functions.name: addClassName
functions.text: Adds a class to a given element

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Classes

functions.name: removeClassName
functions.text: Removes a class from a given element

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Class names to remove. You can either use a space separated string of classnames, comma-separated list or an array

functions.name: setClassName
functions.text:
Alias to addRemoveClassName. 
Utility function, saves many if/elses.

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Class names to add\remove. Comma separated, space separated or simply an Array

params.name: add
params.description: Flag to switch behavior from removal to addition. true to add, false to remove

functions.name: hasClassName
functions.text:
Checks if an element has a class.
This method verifies if an element has ONE of a list of classes. If the last argument is flagged as true, instead checks if the element has ALL the classes

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Class names to test

params.name: all
params.description: If flagged as true, it will check if the element contains ALL the CSS classes

return.description: true if a given class is applied to a given element

functions.name: blinkClass
functions.text:
Blinks a class from an element
Add and removes the class from the element with a timeout, so it blinks

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Class name(s) to blink

params.name: timeout
params.description: timeout in ms between adding and removing, default 100 ms

params.name: negate
params.description: is true, class is removed then added

functions.name: toggleClassName
functions.text: Toggles a class name from a given element

params.name: elm
params.description: DOM element or element id

params.name: className
params.description: Class name

params.name: forceAdd
params.description: Flag to force adding the the classe names if they don't exist yet.

params.name: value

Injects an external link tag.
This method add a stylesheet to the head of a page

functions.name: appendStylesheetCb
functions.text:
Injects an external link tag.
Loads CSS via LINK element inclusion in HEAD (skips append if already there)

Works similarly to appendStylesheet but:
  a) supports all browsers;
  b) supports optional callback which gets invoked once the CSS has been applied

params.name: cssURI
params.description: URI of the CSS to load, if empty ignores and just calls back directly

params.name: callback
params.description: optional callback which will be called once the CSS is loaded

functions.name: decToHex

Converts decimal to hexadecimal values

functions.name: changeFontSize
functions.text:
Change the font size of elements.
Changes the font size of the elements which match the given CSS rule
For this function to work, the CSS file must be in the same domain than the host page, otherwise JS can't access it.

params.name: selector
params.description: CSS selector rule

params.name: delta
params.description: Number of pixels to change on font-size

params.name: op
params.description: Supported operations are '+' and '*'. defaults to '+'

params.name: minVal
params.description: If result gets smaller than minVal, change does not occurr

params.name: maxVal
params.description: If result gets bigger  than maxVal, change does not occurr

functions.text:
Creates a debounced version of a function.
Returns a function which calls `func`, waiting at least `wait` milliseconds between calls. This is useful for events such as `scroll` or `resize`, which can be triggered too many times per second, slowing down the browser with needless function calls.

*note:* This does not delay the first function call to the function.

classes.name: Ink.Dom.FormSerialize
classes.text:
Two way serialization of form data and javascript objects.
Valid applications are ad hoc AJAX/syndicated submission of forms, restoring form values from server side state, etc.

functions.name: serialize
functions.text:
Serializes a form element into a JS object
It turns field names into keys and field values into values.

note: Multi-select and checkboxes with multiple values will result in arrays

params.name: form
params.description: Form element to extract data

return.description: Map of fieldName -> String|String[]|Boolean

examples:
<form id="frm">
        <input type="text" name="field1">
        <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.Dom.FormSerialize_1', 'Ink.Dom.Event_1'], function (FormSerialize, InkEvent) {
            InkEvent.observe('frm', 'submit', function (event) {
                var formData = FormSerialize.serialize('frm'); // -> {field1:"123"}
                InkEvent.stop(event);
            });
        });
    </script>

functions.name: fillIn
functions.text:
Sets form elements' values with values from an object

Note: You can't set the values of an input with `type="file"` (browser prohibits it)

params.name: form
params.description: Form element to be populated

params.name: map2
params.description: Map of fieldName -> String|String[]|Boolean

examples:
<form id="frm">
        <input type="text" name="field1">
        <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.Dom.FormSerialize_1'], function (FormSerialize) {
            var values = {field1: 'CTHULHU'};
            FormSerialize.fillIn('frm', values);
            // At this point the form is pre-filled with the values above.
        });
    </script>

examples:
this._options = Ink.UI.Common.options('MyComponent', {
         'anobject': ['Object', null],  // Defaults to null
         'target': ['Element', null],
         'stuff': ['Number', 0.1],
         'stuff2': ['Integer', 0],
         'doKickFlip': ['Boolean', false],
         'targets': ['Elements'], // Required option since no default was given
         'onClick': ['Function', null]
     }, options || {}, elm)



### Note about booleans

Here is how options are read from the markup
data-attributes, for several values`data-a-boolean`.

Options considered true:

  - `data-a-boolean="true"`
  - (Every other value which is not on the list below.)

Options considered false:

  - `data-a-boolean="false"`
  - `data-a-boolean=""`
  - `data-a-boolean`

Options which go to default:

  - (no attribute). When `data-a-boolean` is ommitted, the
  option is not considered true nor false, and as such
  defaults to what is in the `defaults` argument.

functions.name: ajaxJSON
functions.text:
AJAX JSON request shortcut method
It provides a more convenient way to do an AJAX request and expect a JSON response.
It offers a callback option, as third parameter, for better async handling.

classes.name: Ink.UI.Drawer_1
classes.text:
Displays off-canvas (to the left and to the right) content which can be triggered by clicking elements with the 'left-drawer-trigger' and 'right-drawer-trigger', respectively.

The left drawer has the 'left-drawer' class, and the right drawer has the 'right-drawer' class.

The content drawer (EG your `<div id="main">`) must have the 'content-drawer' class.

For more, see the example below, or try the sample.

functions.name: add
functions.text:
Makes an element droppable and adds it to the stack of droppable elements.
Can consider it a constructor of droppable elements, but where no Droppable object is returned.

In the following arguments, any events/callbacks you may pass, can be either functions or strings. If the 'move' or 'copy' strings are passed, the draggable gets moved into this droppable. If 'revert' is passed, an acceptable droppable is moved back to the element it came from.

params.name: element
params.description: Target element

params.name: options
params.description: options object

params.name: options.hoverClass
params.description: Classname(s) applied when an acceptable draggable element is hovering the element

params.name: options.accept
params.description: Selector for choosing draggables which can be dropped in this droppable.

params.name: options.onHover
params.description: callback called when an acceptable draggable element is hovering the droppable. Gets the draggable and the droppable element as parameters.

params.name: options.onDrop
params.description: callback called when an acceptable draggable element is dropped. Gets the draggable, the droppable and the event as parameters.

params.name: options.onDropOut
params.description: callback called when a droppable is dropped outside this droppable. Gets the draggable, the droppable and the event as parameters. (see above for string options).

examples:
• Draggable 1

  • Draggable 3

classes.name: Ink.UI.LazyLoad_1
classes.text:
Stop the browser from loading a barrage of content at once.

This delays the loading of images and other content until the
corresponding elements are visible in the browser viewport.

This was created to load images later, but can be also used for
widgets which are slow to load and are only useful when on screen.

This works through copying the `src` attribute into `data-src`,
and placing a `placeholder` string in the `src` attribute. Then,
when the element is on screen, the `data-src` attribute is copied
back to `src` and the content starts loading. You can use the options
below to change what attributes are involved in the exchange.

You can also provide your `onInsideViewport` callback and use it to
start widgets which need javascript, such as an interactive map
or an animation.

params.name: rootElement
params.description: {String|DOMElement} The element which contains the lazily-loaded items.

params.name: options
params.description: Options object, containing:

params.name: options.item
params.description: {String} Use this to select and define what is to be considered an `item`.

params.name: options.placeholder
params.description: {String} Placeholder value for items which are still outside the screen (in case they don't already have a value set)

params.name: options.source
params.description: {String} When an `item` is within the viewport, take the value it has in this attribute then set its `destination` attribute to it.

params.name: options.destination
params.description: {String} attribute which gets the value in `source` when the element is visible.

params.name: options.delay
params.description: {Number} Wait a few milliseconds before trying to load.

params.name: options.delta
params.description: {Number} Distance in px from the outside of the viewport. Elements touching within this "margin", items are considered to be inside even if they are outside the viewport limits. Can be negative if you want an element to be considered inside only when it is a certain distance into the viewport.

params.name: options.image
params.description: {Boolean} Set to false to make this component do nothing to any elements and just give you the onInsideViewport callback.

params.name: options.scrollElement
params.description: {Element} (advanced) What element is to be listened for the scroll event.

params.name: options.touchEvents
params.description: {Boolean} Subscribe to touch events in addition to scroll events. Useful in mobile safari because 'scroll' events aren't frequent enough.

params.name: options.onInsideViewport
params.description: {Function} Called when an `item` is within the viewport. Receives `{ element }`

params.name: options.onAfterAttributeChange
params.description: {Function} (advanced) Called after `source` is copied over to `destination`. Receives `{ element }`

params.name: options.autoInit
params.description: {Boolean} (advanced) Set to false if you want to start LazyLoad yourself with `reload()`

classes.name: Ink.UI.Stacker_1
classes.text:
This module combines several stacks of items together, in smaller screen sizes.

The purpose is to have several stacks of items which may have different heights and as such cannot be used because of `float: left` quirks.

For example, when you have three different columns of information:

    [col. A: 1] [col. B: 1] [col. C: 1]
    [col. B: 2] [col. C: 2] [col. C: 2]

and the screen resizes and you need a layout of 2 columns, Stacker reorders the stacks so that you get:

    [col. A: 1] [col. B: 1]
    [col. C: 1] [col. A: 2]
    [col. B: 2] [col. C: 2]

Note: If you just want to use a different amount of columns for your items in several viewports, but these items are guaranteed to have a fixed height, don't use this module. Use the `small-*`, `medium-*` and `large-*` classes instead.

classes.name: Ink.UI.Sticky
classes.text:
The Sticky component takes an element and transforms it's behavior in order to, when the user scrolls he sets its position
to fixed and maintain it until the user scrolls back to the same place.

params.description: Whether to set "style.height" and "style.width" in the stuck element. Turn this off when your `stickyClass` has its own height and width and you don't want this to be dealt with through javascript.

params.name: options.inlinePosition
params.description: Whether to set "style.left" in the stuck element. Turn this off when your `stickyClass` has its own "left" position and you don't want this to be dealt with through javascript.

params.description: Css class for the wrapper element.

params.name: options.stickyClass
params.description: Css class for sticking the sticky to the screen. Add your own "stuck" class to define your own sticky behaviour.

params.name: options.bottomElement

params.description: Layouts in which the sticky behaviour is present. Pass an array or comma-separated string.

examples:
<script>
         Ink.requireModules( ['Ink.Dom.Selector_1','Ink.UI.Sticky_1'], function( Selector, Sticky ) {
             var menuElement = Ink.s('#menu');
             var stickyObj = new Sticky( menuElement );
         });
     </script>

classes.name: Ink.UI.Tooltip
classes.text:
Tooltips are useful as a means to display information about functionality while avoiding clutter.

Tooltips show up when you hover elements which "have" tooltips.

This class will "give" a tooltip to many elements, selected by its first argument (`target`). This is contrary to the other UI modules in Ink, which are created once per element.

You can define options either through the second argument of the Tooltip constructor, or as data-attributes in each `target` element. Options set through data-attributes all start with "data-tip", and override options passed into the Tooltip constructor.

functions.name: Tooltip

params.name: target
params.description: Target element or selector of elements, to display the tooltips on.

params.name: options.text
params.description: Text content for the tooltip.

params.name: options.html
params.description: HTML for the tooltip. Same as above, but won't escape HTML.

params.name: options.where
params.description: Positioning for the tooltip. Options are 'up', 'down', 'left', 'right', which place the tooltip in the corresponding direction (and show an arrow), 'mousemove', which follows the mouse as it moves, and 'mousefix', which stays in one place.

params.name: options.color
params.description: Color of the tooltip. Options are red, orange, blue, green and black. Default is white.

params.name: options.fade
params.description: Fade time; Duration of the fade in/out effect.

params.name: options.forever
params.description: Set to 1/true to prevent the tooltip from being erased when the mouse hovers away from the target

params.name: options.timeout
params.description: Time for the tooltip to live. Useful together with [options.forever].

params.name: options.delay
params.description: Time the tooltip waits until it is displayed. Useful to avoid getting the attention of the user unnecessarily

params.name: options.template
params.description: Element or selector containing HTML to be cloned into the tooltips. Can be a hidden element, because CSS `display` is set to `block`.

params.name: options.templatefield
params.description: Selector within the template element to choose where the text is inserted into the tooltip. Useful when a wrapper DIV is required.

params.name: options.left
params.description: (Nitty-gritty) Spacing from the target to the tooltip, when `where` is `mousemove` or `mousefix`

params.name: options.top
params.description: (Nitty-gritty) Spacing from the target to the tooltip, when `where` is `mousemove` or `mousefix`

params.name: options.spacing
params.description: (Nitty-gritty) Spacing between the tooltip and the target element, when `where` is `up`, `down`, `left`, or `right`

examples:
• New
  • Quit
  • Save
[...]

classes.name: Ink.UI.TreeView
classes.text:
Shows elements in a tree structure which can be expanded and contracted.

A TreeView is built with "node"s and "children". "node"s are `li` tags, and
"children" are `ul` tags.

You can build your TreeView out of a regular UL and  LI element structure which
you already use to display lists with several levels.

If you want a node (LI) to be open when the TreeView is built, just add the 
data-open="true" attribute to it.

functions.name: TreeView

params.description: Options object, containing:

params.name: options.children
params.description: Selector to define which elements are represented as children.

params.name: options.hideClass
params.description: Class to toggle visibility of the children.

params.name: options.iconTag
params.description: The name of icon tag. The component tries to find a tag with that name as a direct child of the node. If it doesn't find it, it creates it.

params.name: options.stopDefault
params.description: Stops the default behavior of the click handler.

examples:
• root

    • child 2
      • grandchild 2a
      • grandchild 2b

    • child 3

functions.name: text
functions.text:
Translates a string.
Given a translation key, return a translated string, with replaced parameters.
When a translated string is not available, the original string is returned unchanged.

params.name: str
params.description: Key to look for in i18n dictionary (which is returned verbatim if unknown)

params.name: namedParms
params.description: Named replacements. Replaces {named} with values in this object.

params.name: args
params.description: Replacement #1 (replaces first {} and all {1})

params.name: arg2
params.description: Replacement #2 (replaces second {} and all {2})

params.name: argn*
params.description: Replacement #n (replaces nth {} and all {n})

examples:
_('Gosto muito de {} e o cu  {}.', 'carros', 'azul');
     // returns 'Gosto muito de carros e o cu  azul.'

_('O {1}  {2} como {2}  a cor do {3}.', 'carro', 'azul', 'FCP');
     // returns 'O carro  azul como azul  o FCP.'

_('O {person1} dava-se com a {person2}', {person1: 'coisinho', person2: 'coisinha'});
     // -> 'O coisinho dava-se com a coisinha'

functions.name: ntext
functions.text:
Translates and pluralizes text.
Given a singular string, a plural string and a number, translates either the singular or plural string.

params.name: strSin
params.description: Word to use when count is 1

params.name: strPlur
params.description: Word to use otherwise

params.name: count
params.description: Number which defines which word to use

params.name: args*
params.description: Extra arguments, to be passed to `text()`

examples:
i18n.ntext('platypus', 'platypuses', 1); // returns 'ornitorrinco'
    i18n.ntext('platypus', 'platypuses', 2); // returns 'ornitorrincos'


    // The "count" argument is passed to text()
    i18n.ntext('{} platypus', '{} platypuses', 1); // returns '1 ornitorrinco'
    i18n.ntext('{} platypus', '{} platypuses', 2); // returns '2 ornitorrincos'

functions.name: ordinal
functions.text:
Gets the ordinal suffix of a number.

This works by using transforms (in the form of Objects or Functions) passed into the function or found in the special key `_ordinals` in the active language dictionary.

params.name: num
params.description: Input number

params.name: options
params.description: Maps for translating. Each of these options' fallback is found in the current language's dictionary. The lookup order is the following: `exceptions`, `byLastDigit`, `default`. Each of these may be either an `Object` or a `Function`. If it's a function, it is called (with `number` and `digit` for any function except for byLastDigit, which is called with the `lastDigit` of the number in question), and if the function returns a string, that is used. If it's an object, the property is looked up using `[...]`. If what is found is a string, it is used.

params.name: options.byLastDigit
params.description: If the language requires the last digit to be considered, mappings of last digits to ordinal suffixes can be created here.

params.name: options.exceptions
params.description: Map unique, special cases to their ordinal suffixes.

return.description: Ordinal suffix for `num`.

functions.name: alias
functions.text:
Alias for the text method.
Returns an alias to `text()`, for convenience. The resulting function is traditionally assigned to "_".

return.description: an alias to `text()`. You can also access the rest of the translation API through this alias.

classes.name: Ink.UI.TagField
classes.text:
Use this class to have a field where a user can input several tags into a single text field. A good example is allowing the user to describe a blog post or a picture through tags, for later searching.

The markup is as follows:

          <input class="ink-tagfield" type="text" value="initial,value">

By applying this UI class to the above input, you get a tag field with the tags "initial" and "value". The class preserves the original input element. It remains hidden and is updated with new tag information dynamically, so regular HTML form logic still applies.

Below "input" refers to the current value of the input tag (updated as the user enters text, of course), and "output" refers to the value which this class writes back to said input tag.

functions.name: TagField

params.name: element
params.description: Selector or DOM Input Element.

params.name: options.tags
params.description: initial tags in the input

params.name: options.allowRepeated
params.description: allow user to input several tags

params.name: options.separator
params.description: Split the input by this RegExp. The default splits by spaces, commas and semicolons

params.name: options.outSeparator
params.description: Use this string to separate each tag from the next in the output.

params.name: options.maxTags
params.description: Maximum amount of tags the user can write.
